discussion.content:
Key words "continually accessible"
This makes option A most appropriate.

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is setting up a web-based application that needs to be continually accessible to the end users. Which of the following concepts would
BEST ensure this requirement?
A wireless client is having issues staying connected to the wireless network even though the client is less than 20ft (6m) from the access point. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause?

comments.content: It absorbs the soul too, just like comptia exam questions.

discussion.content: The machine is located in a CompTIA cubicle that absorbs all radio waves… light too. Kinda like a mini black hole.

Absorption. This is one of the most common reactions we see wireless signal have to materials. Basically, a material is converting the signal's energy into heat. This occurs largely due to the molecules in the medium being unable to move fast enough to “keep up” with the RF waves that are trying to pass through it.
Distance limitations, Latency and Security type mismatch makes no sense in this case.
So what's the correct answer because Absorption doesn't make any sense

comments.content:
He is already connected so why should it be a security type mismatch?
Much more likely that there is a wall in between, I assume some kind of wood absorbs the signal.
ok than explain how you know it's a He

discussion.content: How can this be absorption if the user is within 20ft?! surely it would make more sense if the user couldn't stay connected due to a security type mismatch??
A is correct because Switches create separate collision domains but a single broadcast domain
Collision domains are if an actual single wire is shared with other hosts, like a bus, wireless is actually one collision domain
The answer is just A, routers deal only with broadcast domains.
isn't B besides A also right? https://study-ccna.com/collision-broadcast-domain/

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a network device that is responsible for separating collision domains?
Which of the following network topologies is primarily used to connect servers to large network disk arrays?

discussion.content: A SAN is block-based storage, leveraging a high-speed architecture that connects servers to their logical disk units A is correct
I didnt know SAN was a network topology :/

Network topologies? If I am not mistaken, SAN is a network type meaning there can be different topologies applied to different SANs. Just like how you can have different LANs with different topologies. 

A makes the most sense but I think the question could be worded better.

Selected Answer: C
Because 5 people said its c, with good explanations

Its C, its not B because even though you are on a wireless connection you are trying to gain access to company network. For it to be B they might reference more of a signal based question. then again this is comptia

Please can someone explain why the answer is C? Surely you wouldn't be able to connect to the wireless network at all and would get the error on Windows devices: "Windows was unable to find a certificate to log you on to the network". Surely then if you couldn't connect to the network, then you wouldn't receive an IP from the router/DHCP? Any help is appreciated!

I'd say Incorrect power levels (B). When the power is too low and you are right on the edge of the signal, it will allow you to connect and get an IP, but you won't be able to access anything on the network. I've seen this happen.

comments.content: I think you're right. The key is "Following several attempts" in the question. If it was C then he wouldn't need to try over and over to get an IP.
Because Joe is able to get an IP.

discussion.content: I agree with C, but why is A wrong?

questions.question_text: After setting up in a temporary office, Joe tries to access the company's wireless network. Following several attempts, Joe is able to get an IP, but cannot access network resources. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this error when trying to connect to the company's wireless network?
